did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller personal papers, Art, Series C

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Museum of Primitive Art (New York, N.Y.)

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Art series is divided in 6 subseries:
Subseries 3 - Carol K. Uht Reference Files, 1949-1979

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The files in this series were created in the course of acquiring, managing, and disseminating pieces in Nelson A. Rockefeller's extensive art collection.

For the most part, these are the files of Carol Kinzel Uht, who served as Mr. Rockefeller's full-time curator from December 1949 until her death in 1978. Cynthia Bronson Altman joined the staff in 1971, serving as assistant curator and later as associate curator. Kendall P. Lutkins was responsible for the decorative arts portion of the art collection, including the Chinese pottery and porcelain. After Ms. Uht's death, Ms. Lutkins and Ms. Altman took on most of the curatorial responsibilities and were also responsible for the eventual dissemination of Mr. Rockefeller's art collection in accordance with his will.

The documentation begins with some of Mr. Rockefeller's earliest purchases in 1931 and ends with his death in January 1979. A card file facilitates access to the various correspondence files and offers an abstract of the provenance, management, and disposition of each catalogued work of art.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This brief subseries documents the earliest years of Nelson Rockefeller's collecting activities. It contains correspondence with art dealers regarding works of art for sale, about loans of works owned by Rockefeller to museums and galleries (many of which were declined), and with individual artists. The contents of this subseries were originally organized as Box 67 of the Nelson Rockefeller Possessions series but were incorporated into the Art series when it was archivally processed.

did.unittitle: Works of Art Offered and Declined

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Nelson Rockefeller and artists, dealers, and other collectors offering works of art for sale. Most declined, but a few purchased. The folder also contains a list of NAR's Mexican collection as of 1941.

did.unittitle: Works of Art Offered and Declined

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Nelson Rockefeller and artists, dealers, and other collectors offering works of art for sale. Most declined, but a few purchased.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Nelson Rockefeller and galleries about loans of pieces from his collection to various shows and museums. Many declined.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nelson Rockefeller financed a trip by the artist to Venezuela in 1945. Purchased several watercolors from the artist. Sponsored artist's trip to Brazil and Argentina in 1941. Planned exhibition of paintings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As head of Downtown Gallery, Halpert requests loans of pieces for exhibition and offers pictures for sale; some pieces purchased. Helped establish some of Nelson Rockefeller's earliest collecting decisions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chinese rugs and art purchases for Nelson Rockefeller's apartment. Other items offered but not purchased. Purchase of a ring for his wife, Mary Clark Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of an alphabetical file organized by artist last name and also a numeric file for nonmodern art. Both document the acquisition, provenance, condition, cataloging, placement, and conservation of works of art. The alphabetical file primarily concerns pieces of modern art with documentation for each piece filed under the artist's name. It also contains correspondence with dealers, conservators, galleries, museums, and other institutions regarding the acquisition, care, and loan of works of art. The numeric file is an arrangement created by curator Carol Uht to categorize nonmodern art. Works of art were first designated by geographic region and then arranged by accession number. The index for this file is in Appendix A. Works of art documented within this series were in Nelson Rockefeller's collection at the time of his death in January 1979. Files pertaining to works of art that were no longer in the collection were transferred to the canceled art files (Subseries 6). The NAR art files were periodically sent to the Rockefeller family archives and were maintained there for several years. During that period some documents that do not belong in these files were placed in them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is an alphabetically arranged subject file maintained by Carol Kinzel Uht (CKU), curator to Nelson Rockefeller. It documents broad issues concerning the management of the collection that are not necessarily associated with one particular piece of art. It includes correspondence with galleries, auction houses, dealers, and museums regarding artwork being lent, bought, or sold. There is also internal correspondence regarding the placement and maintenance of works of art, including some owned by other members of the Rockefeller family.

Included in this subseries are files on works belonging to Mr. Rockefeller that were damaged or destroyed in the March 1961 fire at the Executive Mansion in Albany (filed under "Albany"). His support of the Museum of Modern Art and the Museum of Primitive Art is also evident here. There are also files on the expansive exhibition of portions of his collection at Museum of Modern Art in 1969.

scopecontent.p: General correspondence and memoranda concerning loans of NAR artworks, possible purchases and inquiries and comments from the public.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: A complete list of the collection inventories is available at the Rockefeller Archive Center. Please consult an archivist prior to using this subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These inventories were used in conjunction with the other art files to keep track of the art collection. The various photo inventories comprise 4 different sets and were created after Mr. Rockefeller left the Vice Presidency in January 1977. Sets 1 and 2 were located in Mr. Rockefeller's office for easy access.

Set 1 is a complete photo inventory of the art collection in 1977. Other sets focus on Mr. Rockefeller's primitive art collection, which was used to establish the Museum of Primitive Art and later became part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as well as his fine arts objects. Set 4 is organized by the location of a work of art within Mr. Rockefeller's various homes. Additionally, there are three bound volumes titled "Canceled Art," which are inventories of works which were no longer part of the collection (see Subseries 6). Also within this subseries are 16 black binders of photocopies of catalog cards on which the Museum of Primitive Art recorded information regarding individual works of art given to it by Mr. Rockefeller. These indicate the origin of the item and other pertinent information regarding the work that the museum found necessary to have.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Set 1 is a complete photo inventory of Nelson Rockefeller's art collection in 1977 and was originally housed in 24 brown binders. The set begins with photos of contemporary and modern art from the 19th and 20th centuries, which are arranged alphabetically by the artist's last name. Multiple works by the same artist are arranged alphabetically by title or by medium.

The set continues with photos of Rockefeller's nonmodern and primitive art collection from early America, China, Japan, India, Greece, Egypt, and Western Europe, subdivided into geographical sections. Within some sections, the photos are further subdivided by the medium of the art. Each section and subsection is arranged numerically by a two-part inventory number that refers to the geographic region and then to the individual artwork. See Appendix A for the list of definitions of the section numbers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set 4 is an extensive photo inventory documenting Nelson Rockefeller's art collection organized by the location of the artwork in Rockefeller's homes and offices in 1977. The set covers a broad spectrum of media, including sculptures, paintings, furniture, and porcelains. Three location subsets have been rehoused from their original green binders for preservation reasons: West 54th Street and 812 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, as well as Foxhall Road in Washington, DC.

The photographs are first organized according to the property where the art was located and then further divided to reflect the 14 binder volumes in which they were originally housed. The photographs remain in their original order, which seems to reflect a system of categorization created by curator Carol Uht that involves a set of numbers assigned to each photograph. These numbers are recorded on the file level but, unfortunately, their significance remains ambiguous.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The Museum of Primitive Art books, Museum of Modern Art books, and miscellaneous art books have been included in the Rockefeller Archive Center library card catalog. Access to RAC library material is available to onsite researchers only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains auction catalogs, exhibit catalogs, art books and other printed items related to Mr. Rockefeller's interest in art. He read art auction catalogs and gallery brochures as commonly as some people read novels. He usually took some with him on his travels, to scan when he had a free moment. Of particular interest are the auction catalogs that are notated by Mr. Rockefeller to indicate which items he was interested in acquiring. The notations, which were directed to Mrs. Uht, include the maximum amount he was willing to pay for each item. Mrs. Uht sometimes reviewed the catalogs before Mr. Rockefeller did and placed paper clips on pages with items that she thought he might want to purchase.

The exhibit catalogs are primarily from the Museum of Modern Art and the Museum of Primitive Art, both of which he was closely associated with. Mrs. Uht also tried to keep a copy of everything that was published regarding works owned by Mr. Rockefeller, particularly exhibit catalogs that included items borrowed from his collection. There is also about one cubic foot of miscellaneous art books, some in languages other than English.

There are eight volumes of Library Catalogs, which primarily record the location of each of Mr. Rockefeller's many art books. The last two volumes record the location of etchings and drawings owned by Mr. Rockefeller.

Finally, there are 23 volumes of appraisals of portions of Mr. Rockefeller's collections conducted annually from 1962 to 1976. This was done by the Fine Arts Valuation Service, headed by Gustave Gilbert. The works included in each volume are arranged alphabetically by artist and then by title. A catalog number is included as well as the value of the work. Some notations were made showing that an item was going to leave the collection (pledged) or had already left the collection (canceled).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When Mr. Rockefeller parted with a piece of art, through gift, damage, or sale, the piece was recorded as "canceled" and the records concerning it were moved to the Canceled Art File. The file usually notes the name of the individual or institution each work went to, as well as the price for those works that were sold. This subseries also includes a photo file of canceled modern and nonmodern works.
